results.title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
results.abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

results.title: Biden Officials Stave Off Sticker Shock on Medicare Drug Premiums
results.abstract: Federal regulators spent billions of dollars to avoid a spike in costs for older Americans that could have been politically damaging to the presidential campaign of Vice President Kamala Harris.
results.byline: By Rebecca Robbins and Reed Abelson
org_facet: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

multimedia.caption: Without a move by Medicare, some older people would likely have paid hundreds of dollars more annually in insurance premiums.
multimedia.copyright: Ramin Rahimian for The New York Times

results.title: Possible Cluster of Human Bird-Flu Infections Expands in Missouri
results.abstract: Seven people in contact with a patient hospitalized with bird flu also developed symptoms, the C.D.C. reported. Some are undergoing further tests.
results.byline: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Emily Anthes
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: There have been 13 other confirmed cases of H5N1 bird flu in people since the outbreak in dairy cattle was announced in March.
multimedia.copyright: Cynthia Goldsmith/Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

results.title: Acadia Healthcare Says It Faces New Federal Investigations
results.abstract: Shares of the company, one of the largest chains of for-profit psychiatric hospitals, were down 25 percent at one point.
results.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Thomas

multimedia.caption: North Tampa Behavioral Health Hospital is one of more than 50 psychiatric hospitals operated by Acadia Healthcare.

results.title: Risk of Heart Defects Higher in Babies Conceived With I.V.F.
results.abstract: The birth defects were more likely, but still very uncommon, in infants conceived through certain fertility treatments, a large study found.

multimedia.caption: Preparing embryos to test for viability at a fertility clinic in Houston.
Preparing embryos to test for viability at a fertility clinic in Houston.
Preparing embryos to test for viability at a fertility clinic in Houston.

results.title: F.D.A. Approves the First New Schizophrenia Drug in Decades
results.abstract: Available antipsychotic treatments work by blocking dopamine receptors. The new drug, Cobenfy, takes a different approach.
results.byline: By Ellen Barry and Christina Jewett

multimedia.caption: The new drug, Cobenfy, influences dopamine levels like other antipsychotic drugs, but it does so indirectly, by changing levels of another neurotransmitter, acetylcholine.
The new drug, Cobenfy, influences dopamine levels like other antipsychotic drugs, but it does so indirectly, by changing levels of another neurotransmitter, acetylcholine.
The new drug, Cobenfy, influences dopamine levels like other antipsychotic drugs, but it does so indirectly, by changing levels of another neurotransmitter, acetylcholine.

results.title: Acadia Hospitals Reach $20 Million Settlement With Justice Dept.
results.abstract: The F.B.I. is also investigating the large chain of psychiatric hospitals for holding patients longer than what is medically necessary.
results.byline: By Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

multimedia.caption: Jamie Clark Thompson, a whistle-blower who worked as director of nursing at Lakeview Behavioral Health Hospital, an Acadia facility in Norcross, Ga.
multimedia.copyright: Nicole Buchanan for The New York Times

results.title: The Global Threat of Antibiotic Resistance
results.abstract: Health experts, gathering at the U.N., have begun to shift their focus to try to provide access to basic drugs in countries where preventable deaths from infections occur too frequently.

multimedia.caption: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a type of bacteria that causes tuberculosis, has become increasingly resistant to antibiotics.
multimedia.copyright: James Cavallini/BSIP/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images

results.title: A Patchwork of Cannabis Laws Creates Health Risks, Study Finds
results.abstract: A new report calls for public education and closing of legal loopholes to keep the public safe.
org_facet: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine

multimedia.caption: Even as a patchwork of laws and regulations have emerged, the potency of cannabis products has surged.
multimedia.copyright: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times

results.title: A Remote Alaskan Island Is on High Alert for a Rat
results.abstract: Wildlife experts fear that a rat could disrupt the island’s delicate balance, so they are pulling out all the stops.

multimedia.caption: St. Paul Island has been called the Galápagos of the North because of the many species of birds and mammals that call it home.
St. Paul Island has been called the Galápagos of the North because of the many species of birds and mammals that call it home.
St. Paul Island has been called the Galápagos of the North because of the many species of birds and mammals that call it home.

results.title: Lawmakers Seek Inquiry of F.D.A. Device Chief’s Potential Conflicts
results.abstract: A top medical device regulator’s work overlapped at times with his wife’s legal representation of clients with business before the agency.

multimedia.caption: Dr. Jeffrey E. Shuren will retire from the F.D.A. later this year.
Dr. Jeffrey E. Shuren will retire from the F.D.A. later this year.
Dr. Jeffrey E. Shuren will retire from the F.D.A. later this year.

results.title: The Evolution Garden, a Green Journey Through Geologic History
results.abstract: This newly redesigned space at the Natural History Museum in London traces 540 million years of the past while creating an outdoor laboratory for the future.

multimedia.caption: Fern, a life-size bronze Diplodocus skeleton, looming over the new Evolution Garden at London’s Natural History Museum.
multimedia.copyright: The Trustees of the Natural History Museum, London

results.title: Study Finds Climate Change Doubled Likelihood of Recent European Floods
results.abstract: Storm Boris dumped record amounts of rain over Central and Eastern Europe this month. A new study found climate change made the deluge more likely.

multimedia.caption: Firefighters on the flooded streets of Lewin Brzeski, Poland, on Sept. 19.
Firefighters on the flooded streets of Lewin Brzeski, Poland, on Sept. 19.
Firefighters on the flooded streets of Lewin Brzeski, Poland, on Sept. 19.

results.title: That Message From Your Doctor? It May Have Been Drafted by A.I.
results.abstract: Overwhelmed by queries, physicians are turning to artificial intelligence to correspond with patients. Many have no clue that the replies are software-generated.

multimedia.caption: MyChart, the widely used patient portal software, now has a tool powered by A.I. that doctors can use to compose messages to their patients.
MyChart, the widely used patient portal software, now has a tool powered by A.I. that doctors can use to compose messages to their patients.
MyChart, the widely used patient portal software, now has a tool powered by A.I. that doctors can use to compose messages to their patients.

results.title: Punching Octopuses Lead Fish on Hunting Parties
results.abstract: Octopuses and fish are routinely seen working together on the ocean floor, and now scientists say that the cephalopods are the leaders of the pack.

multimedia.caption: A blacktip grouper, right, and a gold-saddle goatfish on a hunting trip with a big blue octopus.
A blacktip grouper, right, and a gold-saddle goatfish on a hunting trip with a big blue octopus.
A blacktip grouper, right, and a gold-saddle goatfish on a hunting trip with a big blue octopus.

results.title: Was It Really a Hot Zone Summer?
results.abstract: From Covid to dengue, viral outbreaks seemed to be popping up all over. But maybe Americans are just more attuned to threats now.

multimedia.caption: Mosquitoes sickened some Americans with infections like dengue, malaria, West Nile virus and Eastern equine encephalitis. But apart from dengue, the outbreaks were not particularly bad.
Mosquitoes sickened some Americans with infections like dengue, malaria, West Nile virus and Eastern equine encephalitis. But apart from dengue, the outbreaks were not particularly bad.
Mosquitoes sickened some Americans with infections like dengue, malaria, West Nile virus and Eastern equine encephalitis. But apart from dengue, the outbreaks were not particularly bad.

results.title: The World Is a Mess. That Makes the Climate Crisis Harder to Solve.
results.abstract: A transformed China, conflicts in Ukraine and elsewhere, and intractable clashes over money have pushed the prospects of progress to a new low.
results.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Max Bearak
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

multimedia.caption: The United Nations headquarters in Manhattan, where the General Assembly begins on Monday.
The United Nations headquarters in Manhattan, where the General Assembly begins on Monday.
The United Nations headquarters in Manhattan, where the General Assembly begins on Monday.

results.title: They’ve Got a Plan to Fight Global Warming. It Could Alter the Oceans.
results.abstract: By tweaking the chemistry of rivers and oceans, humans could remove billions of tons of carbon dioxide from the air. But huge challenges loom.
results.byline: By Brad Plumer, Raymond Zhong and Greta Rybus

multimedia.copyright: Greta Rybus for The New York Times
Greta Rybus for The New York Times
Greta Rybus for The New York Times

results.title: This Shark Lives 400 Years. Its DNA May Explain Why.
results.abstract: Scientists have mapped the genome of the Greenland shark, which could offer clues to the animal’s extreme longevity.

multimedia.caption: In a new study, researchers identified a network of 81 genes that were found only in Greenland sharks and are known to play a role in DNA repair.
In a new study, researchers identified a network of 81 genes that were found only in Greenland sharks and are known to play a role in DNA repair.
In a new study, researchers identified a network of 81 genes that were found only in Greenland sharks and are known to play a role in DNA repair.

results.title: Earth’s Fall Equinox Ushers In Astronomical Autumn
results.abstract: During an equinox, places around the globe experience nearly equal amounts of daytime and nighttime. The second occurrence this year happens on Sunday.

multimedia.caption: Equinoxes occur when Earth reaches a point in its orbit where the sun shines directly on the Equator, occurring twice each year, in March and September
Equinoxes occur when Earth reaches a point in its orbit where the sun shines directly on the Equator, occurring twice each year, in March and September
Equinoxes occur when Earth reaches a point in its orbit where the sun shines directly on the Equator, occurring twice each year, in March and September

results.title: Drug Overdose Deaths Are Dropping. The Reasons Are Not Perfectly Clear.
results.abstract: The decrease across the country is a major breakthrough in efforts to reverse the effects of fentanyl. Researchers and health officials say there is no easy explanation for the trend.

multimedia.caption: Data suggests that some of the tools used to combat opioid overdoses, like the overdose-reversing medication Narcan, were having a significant impact.
multimedia.copyright: Hilary Swift for The New York Times

results.title: The Squishy Truth About Why You’re Seeing Fewer Spotted Lanternflies
results.abstract: Your stomping may have helped trim this invasive insect’s population. But experts say other factors probably explain their reduced numbers around New York City.

multimedia.caption: “We like to think that we’re making a difference by stomping on the spotted lanternfly,” Brian Eshenaur, an invasive species specialist, said.
“We like to think that we’re making a difference by stomping on the spotted lanternfly,” Brian Eshenaur, an invasive species specialist, said.

results.title: What We Know (and Don’t Know) About ‘Forever Chemicals’ in Food
results.abstract: There’s a growing understanding of the health threats of PFAS chemicals in what we eat and drink.

multimedia.caption: PFAS-contaminated beef from a farm in Maine.

results.title: Her Children Were Sick. Was It ‘Forever Chemicals’ on the Family Farm?
results.abstract: Pastures were fertilized with toxic sewage decades ago. Nobody knew, until the cows’ milk was tested.

multimedia.copyright: Greta Rybus for The New York Times
Greta Rybus for The New York Times
Greta Rybus for The New York Times

results.title: Michel Siffre, 85, Dies; Descended Into Caves to Study the Human Mind
results.abstract: He was a pioneer in chronobiology, the study of how our bodies understand the passage of time.

multimedia.caption: Michel Siffre waved to well-wishers before beginning a two-month sojourn in the Clamouse cave in France in November 1999.
Michel Siffre waved to well-wishers before beginning a two-month sojourn in the Clamouse cave in France in November 1999.

results.title: Earth Had a Ring 466 Million Years Ago, Study Says
results.abstract: Impact craters found around the Earth that were made around the same time could be linked to debris falling from a ring, a new study suggests.

multimedia.caption: An artist’s rendering of the Earth surrounded by a temporary ring of debris 466 million years ago.
An artist’s rendering of the Earth surrounded by a temporary ring of debris 466 million years ago.
